<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Aureus (Coin) Portraying Empress Julia Domna  
A.D. 196/211, issued by Septimius Severus  
Gold; diam. 2 cm; 7.34 g  
Mint: Rome  
Obverse: Bust of Julia Domna right, draped  
Inscribed: IVLIA AVGVSTA  
Reverse: Pietas stands left, right hand over lit and garlanded altar, cradles incense box in left arm  
Inscribed: PIETAS AVGG  
RIC IV (Julia Domna) 572; cf. BMCRE V 62–68 (denarii); axis: 12:00  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Martin A. Ryerson, 1922.4883

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">The Syrian-born wife of the African-born emperor Septimius Severus, Julia Domna encouraged interest in philosophy and religion along with the arts; the historian Dio Cassius, the physician Galen, the lawyers Papinian and Ulpian, and other intellectuals were connected with her circle. Her niece, Julia Mamaea, invited Origen to Antioch to discuss Christianity, reflecting the wide interest in religion that the whole Severan dynasty evidenced. Julia’s official portrait, disseminated from Rome, emphasizes an idealized dignity, but her almond-shaped eyes and distinctive hairstyle personalize the image. The inscription PIETAS on the reverse does not refer only to religious piety, but rather to duty or devotion in a broader sense. The inscription is remarkable in that it does not merely refer to Julia’s devotion to her family: the plural ending (AVGG) indicates that the Augusta is being formally associated with her husband in the evocation of devotion to the gods, to the ancestors, and to the state, which is the most important virtue of a ruler.  
Theresa Gross-Diaz

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Levick, Julia Domna, Syrian Empress, pp. 116–18.

Hiesinger, “Julia Domna,” pp. 42–43. The evolution of her hairstyle also helps date images of Julia across the Roman world.

Levick, Julia Domna, Syrian Empress, pp. 94–96. PIETAS AVGG stands for pietas augustorum, “piety of the augustan house.”
